[[File:Taraxacum sect. Ruderalia MHNT.jpg|thumb|The seeds of [[dandelion]]s are adapted to [[wind dispersal]].]] A dispersal vector is an agent of [[biological dispersal]] that moves a dispersal unit, or [[organism]], away from its birth population to another location or population in which the individual will reproduce<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nature.com/scitable/knowledge/library/causes-and-consequences-of-dispersal-in-plants-15927714|title=Causes and Consequences of Dispersal in Plants and Animals|last=Croteau|first=Emily K|date=2010|website=Nature|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name="Schurr2">{{cite book|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pzu4SVKg1PcC&pg=PA206|title=Fruit development and seed dispersal|author1=Frank M. Schurr|author2=Orr Spiegel|author3=Ofer Steinitz|author4=Ana Trakhtenbrot|author5=Asaf Tsoar|author6=Ran Nathan|publisher=[[John Wiley and Sons]]|year=2009|isbn=978-1-4051-8946-0|editor=Lars Østergaard|series=Volume 38 of Annual Plant Reviews|pages=204–237|chapter=Long-Distance Seed Dispersal|doi=10.1002/9781444314557.ch6}}</ref>. These dispersal units can range from pollen to seeds to fungi to entire organisms.
There are two types of dispersal vector, those that are active and those that are passive. Active dispersal involves organisms that are capable of movement under their own energy. In passive dispersal, the organisms have evolved dispersal units, or propagules, that use the kinetic energy of the environment for movement. In plants, some dispersal units have tissue that assists with dispersal and are called "[[Diaspore (botany)|diaspores]]". Some dispersal is self-driven (autochory), such as using gravity (barochory), and does not rely on external vectors. Other types of dispersal are due to external vectors, which can be [[wiktionary:biotic|biotic]] vectors, such as animals (zoochory), or [[Abiotic component|abiotic vectors]], such as the wind (anemochory) or water (hydrochory).<ref name="Schurr2" />
In many cases, organisms will be dispersed by more than one vector before reaching it's final destination. It is often a combination of two or more modes of dispersal that act together to maximize dispersal distance, such as wind blowing a seed into a nearby river, that will carry it farther down stream.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Merritt|first=David M.|last2=Wohl|first2=Ellen E.|date=August 2002|title=PROCESSES GOVERNING HYDROCHORY ALONG RIVERS: HYDRAULICS, HYDROLOGY, AND DISPERSAL PHENOLOGY|journal=Ecological Applications|language=en|volume=12|issue=4|pages=1071–1087|doi=10.1890/1051-0761(2002)012[1071:pgharh]2.0.co;2|issn=1051-0761}}</ref>
== Self Generated Dispersal (Autochory) == [[File:Natural_monument_Kočičí_skály_in_summer_2016_(5).JPG|alt=|left|thumb|200x200px|In [[Leptosporangiate fern|leptosporangiate]] ferns, the fern catapults its [[Spore|spores]] 1-2 cm so they can be picked up by a secondary dispersal vector, predominantly the wind<ref name=":15">{{Cite journal|last=Pajarón|first=Santiago|last2=Pangua|first2=Emilia|last3=Quiles|first3=Laura|date=2017-11-21|title=Autochory in ferns, not all spores are blown with the wind|journal=Plant Biosystems - an International Journal Dealing with All Aspects of Plant Biology|language=en|volume=152|issue=5|pages=979–985|doi=10.1080/11263504.2017.1403395|issn=1126-3504}}</ref>.  ]] ''Main article:'' [[Seed dispersal]]
Autochory is the dispersal of [[Diaspore (botany)|diaspores]], which are dispersal units consisting of seeds or spores, using only the energy provided by the diaspore or the parent plant<ref name=":22" />. The plant of origin is the dispersal vector itself, instead of an external vector<ref name=":22">{{Cite news|url=https://definedterm.com/a/definition/183431|title=DefinedTerm: Autochory|work=Defined Term|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en-US}}</ref>. There are four main types of autochory that act on [[Diaspore (botany)|diaspores]]: ballochory, or violent ejection by the parent organism; blastochory, where a diaspore crawls along the ground using [[Stolon|stolons]]; barochory, the use of [[gravity]] for dispersal; and herpochory, crawling using hygroscopic hairs called [[Trichome|trichomes]] <ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Vegetation Ecology|last=|first=|publisher=Wiley Blackwell|year=2013|isbn=|editor-last=Van der Maarel|editor-first=Eddy|edition=2|location=UK|pages=168, 171, 173|editor-last2=Franklin|editor-first2=Janet}}</ref>.
In some cases, ballochory can be more effective when utilizing a [[Diplochory|secondary dispersal vector]]<ref name=":15" />: ejecting the seeds in order for them to use wind or water for longer distance dispersal.
== Animals (Zoochory) == Animal-mediated dispersal is called zoochory<ref name=":1" />. Zoochory can be further described by which animal is acting as a dispersal vector. Animals are an important dispersal vector because they provide the ability to transfer dispersal units longer distances than their parent organism can. The main groups include dispersal by [[Bird|birds]] (Ornithochory), dispersal by [[Ant|ants]] ([[Myrmecochory|Myrmekochory]]), dispersal by [[Mammal|mammals]] (Mammaliochory), dispersal by [[Amphibian|amphibians]] or [[Reptile|reptiles]], and dispersal by [[Insect|insects]], such as [[Bee|bees]]<ref name=":1" />.
Animals are also a large contributor to [[pollination]] via [[Zoophily]]. Flowering plants overwhelmingly are pollinated by animals, and while [[Invertebrate|invertebrates]] are involved in the majority of that pollination, birds and mammals also play a role<ref name=":04">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/earth/story/20150514-extraordinary-pollinators|title=Animals you might not know pollinate flowers|last=Douglass|first=Michelle|language=en|access-date=2018-10-26}}</ref>.
=== Ornithochory === [[File:Owl_Pellet_-_Flickr_-_gailhampshire.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Owl_Pellet_-_Flickr_-_gailhampshire.jpg|alt=|thumb|Barn owl pellets containing pouched mouse remains have been found to contain germinating seeds.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dean|first=W. R. J.|last2=Milton|first2=Suzanne J.|date=1988|title=Dispersal of seeds by raptors|journal=African Journal of Ecology|language=en|volume=26|issue=2|pages=173–176|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2028.1988.tb00967.x|issn=0141-6707}}</ref>]] [[Bird|Birds]] contribute to [[seed dispersal]] in several ways that are unique from general vectors. Birds often cache, or store, the seeds of trees and shrubs for later consumption; only some of these seeds are later recovered and eaten, so many of the seeds are able to utilize the behavior of seed caching to allow them to [[Germination|germinate]] away from the mother tree <ref name=":1" />.
Long-distance dispersal, which is rare for a parent plant to achieve alone, could be mediated by migratory movements of birds. Long-distance dispersal operates over spatial areas that span thousands of kilometers, which allow it to promote rapid range shifts and determine species distributions<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.cell.com/trends/ecology-evolution/fulltext/S0169-5347(16)30113-6|title=Migratory Birds as Global Dispersal Vectors|last=Viana|first=Duarte S.|date=July 5, 2016|journal=Trends in Ecology & Evolution|volume=31|issue=10|pages=763–775|archive-url=http://www.cell.com/trends/ecology-evolution/fulltext/S0169-5347(16)30113-6|archive-date=April 19, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=|doi=10.1016/j.tree.2016.07.005|pmid=27507683|hdl=10261/138397}}</ref>.
In [[seed dispersal]], [[ingestion]] of seeds that are capable of resisting digestive juices allows the [[Seed|seeds]] to be scattered in [[feces]] and dispersed far from the parent organism<ref name=":0" />. For these seeds, gut passage enhances [[germination]] ability when the seeds are ingested by [[Bird|birds]] and [[Mammal|mammals]]<ref name=":1" />.
Finally, ingestion of [[Herbivore|herbivores]] by [[Carnivore|carnivorous]] animals may help disperse seeds by preying on primary seed dispersers such as herbivores or [[Omnivore|omnivores]] <ref name=":19" />. When a bird is eaten by a cat or another carnivore, that animal will inadvertently consume the seeds that the prey species consumed. These seeds may then be later deposited in a process called [[diplochory]], where a seed is moved by more than one dispersal vector, which is important for seed dispersal outcomes as carnivores range widely and enhance the genetic connectivity of dispersed populations<ref name=":19">{{Cite journal|last=Hämäläinen|first=Anni|last2=Broadley|first2=Kate|last3=Droghini|first3=Amanda|last4=Haines|first4=Jessica A.|last5=Lamb|first5=Clayton T.|last6=Boutin|first6=Stan|last7=Gilbert|first7=Sophie|date=2017-02|title=The ecological significance of secondary seed dispersal by carnivores|journal=Ecosphere|language=en|volume=8|issue=2|pages=e01685|doi=10.1002/ecs2.1685|issn=2150-8925}}</ref>.
Birds act as dispersal vectors for non-seed dispersal units as well. Hummingbirds spread pollen on their beaks<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Linhart|first=Yan B.|date=1973|title=Ecological and Behavioral Determinants of Pollen Dispersal in Hummingbird- Pollinated Heliconia|journal=The American Naturalist|volume=107|issue=956|pages=511–523|jstor=2459823}}</ref>, and fungal spores may stick to the bottom of birds’ feet<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Evans|first=Raymond N.|last2=Prusso|first2=Don C.|date=1969|title=Spore Dispersal by Birds|journal=Mycologia|volume=61|issue=4|pages=832–835|doi=10.2307/3757475|jstor=3757475}}</ref>. Water birds may also help to disperse aquatic invertebrates, specifically [[Brachiopod|branchiopods]], [[Ostracod|ostracods]], and [[Bryozoa|bryozoans]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brochet|first=A. L.|last2=Gauthier-Clerc|first2=M.|last3=Guillemain|first3=M.|last4=Fritz|first4=H.|last5=Waterkeyn|first5=A.|last6=Baltanás|first6=Á.|last7=Green|first7=A. J.|date=2009-11-12|title=Field evidence of dispersal of branchiopods, ostracods and bryozoans by teal (Anas crecca) in the Camargue (southern France)|journal=Hydrobiologia|language=en|volume=637|issue=1|pages=255–261|doi=10.1007/s10750-009-9975-6|issn=0018-8158|hdl=10261/38737}}</ref>.
=== [[Myrmecochory]] === ''Main article:'' [[Myrmecochory]]
This includes all of the dispersal caused by [[Ant|ants]], including seed dispersal and the dispersal of leaf matter from trees.
=== Mammaliochory === Similarly to birds, dispersal by [[Mammal|mammals]] allows for long distance dispersal, especially via carnivores. The act of carnivores eating primary dispersal vectors (herbivores) can lead to long distance dispersal and connection between different populations of the same species because of large predator ranges in comparison to smaller herbivore ranges<ref name=":19" /><ref name=":0" />. Mammals have been shown to act as dispersal vectors for seeds, spores, and [[Parasitism|parasites]].
Just as in ornithocory, ingestion by herbivores acts as a dispersal vector for seeds, and gut passage increases the rate of [[germination]] <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Anne Bråthen|first=Kari|last2=T. González|first2=Victoria|last3=Iversen|first3=Marianne|last4=Killengreen|first4=Siw|last5=T. Ravolainen|first5=Virve|last6=A. Ims|first6=Rolf|last7=G. Yoccoz|first7=Nigel|date=2007|title=Endozoochory varies with ecological scale and context|journal=Ecography|language=en|volume=30|issue=2|pages=308–320|doi=10.1111/j.0906-7590.2001.04976.x|issn=0906-7590}}</ref><ref name=":20">{{Cite journal|last=Boch|first=Steffen|last2=Berlinger|first2=Matthias|last3=Prati|first3=Daniel|last4=Fischer|first4=Markus|date=2015-12-17|title=Is fern endozoochory widespread among fern-eating herbivores?|journal=Plant Ecology|language=en|volume=217|issue=1|pages=13–20|doi=10.1007/s11258-015-0554-9|issn=1385-0237}}</ref>. [[File:Large-spotted_Genet_(Genetta_tigrina)_(17356502041)_(crop).jpg|alt=|left|thumb|220x220px|Cape Genets have been found to act as pollinators when they drink nectar from flowers<ref name=":04" />.]][[Marsupial|Marsupials]], [[Primate|primates]], [[Rodent|rodents]], [[Bat|bats]], and some species in the suborder [[Feliformia]] ([[Cape gray mongoose|Cape grey mongooses]] and [[Cape genet|Cape genets]]) have all been identified as pollinators<ref name=":16">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/earth/story/20150514-extraordinary-pollinators|title=Animals you might not know pollinate flowers|last=Douglass|first=Michelle|language=en|access-date=2018-10-26}}</ref><ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|date=1997-03-01|title=Non-flying mammals as pollinators|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0169534796100677|journal=Trends in Ecology & Evolution|language=en|volume=12|issue=3|pages=104–108|doi=10.1016/S0169-5347(96)10067-7|issn=0169-5347|last1=Carthew|first1=S.}}</ref>. Non-flying mammals have been identified as acting as pollinators in Australia, Africa, South and Central America. Some plants may have traits that coevolved to utilize mammals as dispersal vectors, such as being extremely pungent in odor, nocturnal nectar production, and robust flowers that can handle rough feeders <ref name=":12" />. The [[pollen]] of some plants can be found stuck to the fur of mammals as well as accidentally ingested when [[nectar]] is consumed<ref name=":12" />. [[File:Deer_Mouse_(Peromyscus_maniculatus)_(9310532204).jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Deer_Mouse_(Peromyscus_maniculatus)_(9310532204).jpg|alt=|thumb|200x200px|Diaspores from 6 different bryophytes have been found on the fur of American red squirrels, Northern flying squirrels, and deer mice<ref name=":17">{{Cite journal|last=Barbé|first=Marion|last2=Chavel|first2=Émilie E.|last3=Fenton|first3=Nicole J.|last4=Imbeau|first4=Louis|last5=Mazerolle|first5=Marc J.|last6=Drapeau|first6=Pierre|last7=Bergeron|first7=Yves|date=2016|title=Dispersal of bryophytes and ferns is facilitated by small mammals in the boreal forest|journal=Écoscience|language=en|volume=23|issue=3–4|pages=67–76|doi=10.1080/11956860.2016.1235917|issn=1195-6860}}</ref>.]] Mammals contribute to [[bryophyte]] and [[fern]] spore dispersal by carrying [[Spore|spores]] on their fur. Small mammals acting as dispersal vectors may have advantages for the dispersing organism compared to wind transport, as the mammals share similar [[Ecosystem|ecosystems]] to the parent plant, while wind transport is random. Additionally, mammals can transport spores that have qualities such as low production and non-wind adapted morphology that wouldn't be conducive for wind transport<ref name=":17" />.
[[Dik-dik]], (''Madoqua kirkii''), [[Grant's gazelle]] (''Gazella granti''), and [[impala]] (''Aepyceros melampus'') become infected by gastrointestinal nematode parasites that lay on vegetation the antelope consume<ref name=":18" />. Once infected, they disperse [[nematode]] [[Parasitism|parasites]] in their feces <ref name=":18">{{Cite journal|last=Ezenwa|first=Vanessa O.|date=2004|title=Selective Defecation and Selective Foraging: Antiparasite Behavior in Wild Ungulates?|journal=Ethology|language=en|volume=110|issue=11|pages=851–862|doi=10.1111/j.1439-0310.2004.01013.x|issn=0179-1613}}</ref>. Once consumed, the eggs are spread to a new area via the defecation of small mounds of dung<ref name=":18" />.
=== Dispersal by Amphibians or Reptiles === [[Frog|Frogs]] and [[Lizard|lizards]] have been found to be dispersal vectors for [[Crustacean|crustaceans]] and [[ring worms]], specifically [[Bromeliaceae|bromeliad]] [[Ostracod|ostracods]] (''Elpidium bromeliarum)'' and [[Annelid|annelids]] (''Dero superterrenus''). Annelids showed a strong chemical orientation towards moist frog skin that may have developed to diminish risk of dehydration during transport in the environment. The ostracods have frequently been found to be attached to frogs in order to colonize new areas<ref name=":21" />. Both ostracods and annelids will attach themselves to lizards as well, but they prefer to attach themselves to frogs.<ref name=":21">{{Cite journal|last=Lopez|first=Luiz Carlos Serramo|last2=Filizola|first2=Bruno|last3=Deiss|first3=Isabela|last4=Rios|first4=Ricardo Iglesias|date=2005|title=Phoretic Behaviour of Bromeliad Annelids (Dero) and Ostracods (Elpidium) using Frogs and Lizards as Dispersal Vectors|journal=Hydrobiologia|language=en|volume=549|issue=1|pages=15–22|doi=10.1007/s10750-005-1701-4|issn=0018-8158}}</ref>
=== Dispersal by Invertebrates === ''Main article:'' [[Pollination]] and [[Pollinator|Pollinators]]
One of the most important examples of dispersal via [[Invertebrate|invertebrates]] are pollinators such as bees, flies, wasps, beetles, and butterflies<ref name=":04" />.
Invertebrates may also act as dispersal vectors for the spores of ferns and bryophytes via [[endozoochory]], or the ingestion of the plant<ref name=":20" />.
== Wind (Anemochory) == Anemochory is dispersal of units by wind. Wind is a major vector of long distance dispersal that is responsible for the spread and propagation of species to new habitats.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Soons|first=Merel B.|last2=Bullock|first2=James M.|date=2008|title=Non-random seed abscission, long-distance wind dispersal and plant migration rates|journal=Journal of Ecology|language=en|volume=96|issue=4|pages=581–590|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2745.2008.01370.x|issn=0022-0477}}</ref> Each species has its own "wind dispersal potential", which is the proportion of dispersal units that travel farther than a predefined reference distance travelled under normal [[weather]] conditions.<ref name=":152">{{Cite journal|last=Tackenberg|first=Oliver|last2=Poschlod|first2=Peter|last3=Bonn|first3=Susanne|date=2003|title=ASSESSMENT OF WIND DISPERSAL POTENTIAL IN PLANT SPECIES|journal=Ecological Monographs|language=en|volume=73|issue=2|pages=191–205|doi=10.1890/0012-9615(2003)073[0191:aowdpi]2.0.co;2|issn=0012-9615}}</ref> The effectiveness of wind dispersal relies predominantly on the morphological traits and adaptations of the dispersal units and wind conditions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Okubo|first=Akira|last2=Levin|first2=Simon A.|date=1989|title=A Theoretical Framework for Data Analysis of Wind Dispersal of Seeds and Pollen|journal=Ecology|volume=70|issue=2|pages=329–338|doi=10.2307/1937537|jstor=1937537}}</ref> The two main traits of plants that predict their wind dispersal potential are falling [[velocity]] and initial release height of the dispersal unit. Higher falling velocity is generally correlated with heavier seeds, which have a lower wind dispersal potential because it takes a stronger wind to carry them.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Okubo|first=Akira|last2=Levin|first2=Simon A.|date=1989|title=A Theoretical Framework for Data Analysis of Wind Dispersal of Seeds and Pollen|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/1937537|journal=Ecology|volume=70|issue=2|pages=329–338|doi=10.2307/1937537}}</ref> The taller the initial release height of the dispersal unit, the larger the wind dispersal potential because there is a larger window in which it can be picked up by the wind.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Soons|first=Merel B.|last2=Nathan|first2=Ran|last3=Katul|first3=Gabriel G.|date=2004|title=HUMAN EFFECTS ON LONG-DISTANCE WIND DISPERSAL AND COLONIZATION BY GRASSLAND PLANTS|url=https://esajournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1890/03-0398|journal=Ecology|language=en|volume=85|issue=11|pages=3069–3079|doi=10.1890/03-0398|issn=0012-9658|via=}}</ref>
=== Adaptive Morphology === Many species have evolved morphological adaptations to maximize wind dispersal potential. Common examples include plumed, winged, and balloon-like [[Diaspore (botany)|diaspores.]]<ref name=":152" /> [[File:Waiting_For_The_Wind_(222218757).jpeg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Waiting%20For%20The%20Wind%20(222218757).jpeg|thumb|Plumed diaspores of the dandelion, ''Taraxacum officinale.'']] Plumed diaspores have thin hair-like projections that allow easier wind uplift.<ref name=":152" /> One of the most common plumed species is the dandelion, ''Taraxacum officinale''. The wind dispersal potential of plumed species are directly correlated to the total mass and total surface area of the projected plume.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Casseau|first=Vincent|last2=De Croon|first2=Guido|last3=Izzo|first3=Dario|last4=Pandolfi|first4=Camilla|date=2015-05-04|title=Morphologic and Aerodynamic Considerations Regarding the Plumed Seeds of Tragopogon pratensis and Their Implications for Seed Dispersal|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4418730/|journal=PLoS ONE|volume=10|issue=5|pages=e0125040|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0125040|issn=1932-6203|pmc=4418730|pmid=25938765}}</ref> [[File:Picea_abies_seeds_with_wings.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Picea_abies_seeds_with_wings.jpg|left|thumb|Winged seeds of the Norway spruce, ''Picea abies.'']] Winged diaspores have fibrous tissue that develops on the wall of the seed and projects outward<ref name=":23" /> . Seed wings are generally thought to co-evolve with the evolution of larger seeds, in order to increase dispersal and offset the weight of the larger seeds.<ref name=":23">{{Cite journal|last=Telenius|first=Anders|last2=Torstensson|first2=Peter|date=1991|title=Seed Wings in Relation to Seed Size in the Genus Spergularia|journal=Oikos|volume=61|issue=2|pages=216–222|doi=10.2307/3545339|jstor=3545339}}</ref> Some common examples include [[pine]] and [[Spruce|spruce trees]].
Balloon-like seeds are a phenomenon where the [[calyx]], a kind of protective pouch or covering the plant uses to guard the seeds, is light and swollen.<ref name=":152" /> This ballon-like structure allows the entire pouch of seeds to be dispersed by gusts of wind.<ref name=":152" /> A common example of the balloon-like diaspore is the ''Trifolium fragiferum,'' or strawberry clover.
=== Human Effects on Anemochory === Wind dispersal of a particular species can also be affected by human actions.<ref name=":162">{{Cite journal|last=Soons|first=Merel B.|last2=Nathan|first2=Ran|last3=Katul|first3=Gabriel G.|date=2004|title=HUMAN EFFECTS ON LONG-DISTANCE WIND DISPERSAL AND COLONIZATION BY GRASSLAND PLANTS|journal=Ecology|language=en|volume=85|issue=11|pages=3069–3079|doi=10.1890/03-0398|issn=0012-9658}}</ref> Humans can affect anemochory in three major ways: habitat fragmentation, chemical runoff, and climate change.<ref name=":162" />
Clearing land for development and building roads through forests can lead to [[habitat fragmentation]]. [[Habitat fragmentation]] reduces the number and size of the effected populations, which reduces the amount of seeds that are dispersed.<ref name=":162" />This lowers the probability that dispersed seeds with germinate and take root.<ref name=":162" />
Chemical runoff from fertilizer, leakages of sewage, and carbon emissions from [[Fossil fuel|fossil fuels]] can also lead to [[eutrophication]], a build up of nutrients that often leads to excess algae and non-native plant growth.<ref name=":162" /> Eutrophication can lead to decreased long distance dispersal because the lack of nutrients to native plants causes a decrease in seed release height.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Soons|first=Merel B.|last2=Nathan|first2=Ran|last3=Katul|first3=Gabriel G.|date=2004|title=HUMAN EFFECTS ON LONG-DISTANCE WIND DISPERSAL AND COLONIZATION BY GRASSLAND PLANTS|url=https://esajournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1890/03-0398|journal=Ecology|language=en|volume=85|issue=11|pages=3069–3079|doi=10.1890/03-0398|issn=0012-9658|via=}}</ref> However, because of the lowered release height, eutrophication can sometimes lead to an increase in short distance dispersal.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Soons|first=Merel B.|last2=Nathan|first2=Ran|last3=Katul|first3=Gabriel G.|date=2004|title=HUMAN EFFECTS ON LONG-DISTANCE WIND DISPERSAL AND COLONIZATION BY GRASSLAND PLANTS|url=https://esajournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1890/03-0398|journal=Ecology|language=en|volume=85|issue=11|pages=3069–3079|doi=10.1890/03-0398|issn=0012-9658|via=}}</ref>
Climate change effects on wind patterns have the potential increase average wind velocity.<ref name=":162" /> However, it can also lead to lower levels of wind dispersal for each individual plant or organism because of the effects [[climate change]] has on the normal conditions needed for plant growth, such as temperature and rainfall.<ref name=":162" />
== Water (Hydrochory) == Hydrochory is dispersal using water, including oceans, rivers, streams, and rain.<ref name=":3" /> It affects many different dispersal units, such as seeds, [[Fern sports|fern spores]], [[zooplankton]], and [[plankton]].
Terrestrial water sources tend to be more restricted in their ability to disperse units<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Robinson|first=L. M.|date=November 2011|title=Pushing the limits in marine species distribution modelling: lessons from the land present challenges and opportunities|journal=Global Ecology and Biogeography|volume=20|issue=6|pages=789–802|doi=10.1111/j.1466-8238.2010.00636.x}}</ref>. Barriers such as mountain ranges, farm land, and urban centers prevent the relatively free movement of dispersal units seen in open bodies of water<ref name=":2" />. [[Oceanic dispersal]] can move individuals or reproductive propagules anywhere from a meter to hundreds of kilometers from the original point depending on the size of the individual<ref name=":3" /> <ref name=":2" />.
=== Marine Dispersal === ''Related Article:'' [[Oceanic dispersal|Ocean dispersal]].
A majority of marine organisms utilize [[Ocean current|ocean currents]] and movement within the [[water column]] to reproduce<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Gaylord|first=Brian|date=May 2002|title=A physically based model of macroalgal spore dispersal in the wave and current-dominated nearshore|url=|journal=Ecology|volume=83|issue=5|pages=1239–1251|via=Wiley}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Richardson|first=Mark F.|date=2016|title=Multiple dispersal vectors drive range expansion in an invasive marine species|url=|journal=Molecular Ecology|volume=25|issue=20|pages=5001–5014|via=|pmid=27552100|doi=10.1111/mec.13817}}</ref>. The process of releasing reproductive propagules into the water is called broadcast [[Spawn (biology)|spawning]] <ref name=":2" /><ref name=":5" />. While broadcast spawning requires parents to be relatively close to each other for fertilization, the fertilized [[zygote]]<nowiki/>s can be moved extreme distances<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hobday|first=Alistair J.|date=2001|title=Over-exploitation of a broadcast spawning marine invertebrate: Decline of the white abalone|url=|journal=Reviews in Fish Biology and Fisheries|volume=10|pages=493–514|via=}}</ref>. A number of marine invertebrates require ocean currents to connect their gametes once broadcast spawning has occurred <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Morita|first=Masaya|date=May 2009|title=Ocean acidification reduces sperm flagellar motility in broadcast spawning reef invertebrates|url=|journal=Zygote|volume=18|pages=103–107|via=}}</ref>. [[Kelp]], an important group of sea plants, primarily utilize ocean currents to distribute their spores and larvae<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Reed|first=Daniel C.|last2=Amsler|first2=Charles D.|last3=Ebeling|first3=Alfred W.|date=October 1992|title=Dispersal in kelps: Factors affecting spore swimming and competency|url=|journal=Ecology|volume=73|issue=5|pages=1577–1585|via=}}</ref>. Many coral species reproduce by releasing gametes into the water column with hopes that other local corals will also release gametes before these units are dispersed by ocean currents<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Negri|first=A. P.|last2=Webster|first2=N. S.|last3=Hill|first3=R. T.|last4=Heyward|first4=A. J.|date=November 2001|title=Metamorphosis of broadcast spawning corals in response to bacteria isolated from crustose algae|url=|journal=Marine Ecology Progress Series|volume=223|pages=121–131|via=}}</ref>.
Some non-submerged aquatic plant species, like palm trees and mangroves, have developed fruits that float in sea water in order to utilize ocean currents as a form of dispersal<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Nathan|first=Ran|date=2008|title=Mechanisms of long-distance seed dispersal|url=|journal=Trends in Ecology and Evolution|volume=23|pages=638–647|via=Elsevier}}</ref>. Coconuts have been found to travel up to thousands of miles away from their parent tree due to their [[Buoyancy|buoyant]] nature<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Howe|first=Henry F.|last2=Smallwood|first2=Judith|date=1982|title=Ecology of Seed Dispersal|url=|journal=Annual Review of Ecology and Systematics|volume=13|pages=201–228|via=}}</ref>. A variety of over 100 species of vascular plants utilize this dispersal method for their fruit<ref name=":3" />.
Many plants have evolved with specific adaptations to maximize the distance that seeds, fruits, or propagules are dispersed in the ocean. For an increased protection against sinking in the [[water column]], seeds have developed hair or slime on their outer [[Seed-coat|seed coats]]<ref name=":6" />. Seeds with filled with air, cork, or oil are better prepared to float for farther distances<ref name=":6" />.
Another aspect of dispersal comes from wave and tidal action<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=McMahon|first=Kathryn|date=November 2014|title=The movement ecology of seagrass|url=|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society of London B: Biological Sciences|volume=281|pages=1–9|via=}}</ref>. Organisms in shallower waters, such as seagrasses, become displaced and dispersed by waves crashing upon them and tides pulling them out into the open ocean<ref name=":7" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kendrick|first=Gary A.|date=January 2012|title=The central role of dispersal in the maintenance and persistence of seagrass populations|url=|journal=BioScience|volume=62|pages=56–65|via=JSTOR}}</ref>. [[File:Table iceberg west of Sjuøyane, Arctic ocean.jpg|thumb|An iceberg that may act as a raft for arctic invertebrates. ]] Some smaller marine organisms maximize their own dispersal by attaching to a raft - a biotic or abiotic object that is being moved by the ocean’s currents<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Winston|first=Judith E.|date=October 2012|title=Dispersal in marine organisms without a pelagic larval phase|url=|journal=Integrative and Comparative Biology|volume=52|pages=447–457|via=JSTOR}}</ref>. Biotic rafts can be floating seeds or fruits, leaves, or other propagules<ref name=":8" />. Abiotic rafts are usually floating woods or plastics, including buoys and discarded trash<ref name=":8" />.
[[Sea ice]] is also an important dispersal vector. Some arctic species rely on sea ice to disperse their eggs, like ''Daphnia pulex''<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Havel|first=John E.|last2=Shurin|first2=Jonathan B.|date=July 2004|title=Mechanisms, effects, and scales of dispersal in freshwater zooplankton|url=|journal=Limnology and Oceanography|volume=49|pages=1229–1238|via=JSTOR}}</ref>''.'' Drifting, as discussed above, can be an effective dispersal vector for marine mammals. It has been shown that intertidal [[Benthic zone|benthic]] invertebrates will utilize sea ice as a raft to travel up to multiple kilometers<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Macfarlane|first=Colin B. A.|date=January 2013|title=Dispersal of marine benthic invertebrates through ice rafting|url=|journal=Ecology|volume=94|pages=250–256|via=Wiley}}</ref>.
=== Freshwater Dispersal === Freshwater dispersal primarily occurs through flowing water transporting dispersal units<ref name=":9" />. Permanent aquatic environments require outside forms of dispersal to retain biodiversity, so hydrochory via freshwater is vital for the success of terrestrial water sources<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Vanschoenwinkel|first=Bram|date=2008|title=Relative importance of different dispersal vectors for small aquatic invertebrates in a rock pool metacommunity|url=|journal=Ecography|volume=31|pages=567–577|via=}}</ref>. Lakes remain genetically diverse thanks to rivers that connect lakes to new sources of biodiversity<ref name=":9" />. In lakes that lack connecting rivers, some organisms have developed adaptations that utilize the wind, while in an aquatic environment, to disperse reproductive units<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Incagnone|first=Giulia|date=2015|title=How do freshwater organisms cross the "dry ocean"? A review on passive dispersal and colonization processes with a special focus on temporary ponds|url=|journal=Hydrobiologia|volume=750|pages=103–123|via=}}</ref>. In these cases, the dispersal units are moved to new aquatic habitats by utilizing the wind instead of the water in their habitat. [[File:The Flowing River.jpg|thumb|Flowing rivers can act as dispersal vectors for plant matter and invertebrates. ]] Running water is the only form of long distance dispersal present in freshwater sources, so rivers act as the main aquatic terrestrial dispersal vector<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Battauz|first=Yamila S.|date=2017|title=Macrophytes as dispersal vectors of zooplankton resting stages in a subtropical riverine floodplain|url=|journal=Aquatic Ecology|volume=51|pages=191–201|via=}}</ref>. Like in marine ecosystems, organisms take advantage of flowing water via passive transport of drifting along on a raft<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bilton|first=David T.|date=2001|title=Dispersal in freshwater invertebrates|url=|journal=Annual Review of Ecology and Systematics|volume=32|pages=159–181|via=JSTOR}}</ref>. The distance traveled by floating or drifting organisms and propagules is determined primarily on the amount of time that organism or unit is able to retain [[buoyancy]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Donnelly|first=Melinda J.|last2=Walters|first2=Linda J.|date=November 2008|title=Water and boating activity as dispersal vectors for Schinus terebinthifolius (Brazilian pepper) seeds in freshwater and estuarine habitats|url=|journal=Estuaries and Coasts|volume=31|pages=960–968|via=JSTOR}}</ref>.  
Freshwater is important for dispersal of non-aquatic terrestrial organisms as well. [[Bryophyte|Bryophytes]] require an external source of water in order to sexually reproduce. Some bryophytes also utilize falling rain drops to maximize their spore dispersal distances<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sundberg|first=Sebastian|date=January 2005|title=Larger capsules enhance short-range spore dispersal in Sphagnum, but what happens further away?|url=|journal=Oikos|volume=108|pages=115–124|via=JSTOR}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fitt|first=B. D. L.|date=1987|title=Spore dispersal and plant disease gradients; a comparison between two empirical models|url=|journal=Journal of Phytopathology|volume=118|pages=227–242|via=}}</ref>.
=== Extreme Weather === Extreme weather events ([[Tropical cyclone|tropical cyclones]], floods and heavy rains, hurricanes, and thunderstorms) are the most intense examples of water functioning as a vector<ref name=":3" />. The high intensity and high volume of rain that comes with these events facilitate long distance dispersal<ref name=":3" />.
Overflow is traditionally a side effect of heavy rains impacting one specific area<ref name=":11" />. Overflows have been shown to be effective in transmitting [[biodiversity]] between temporary lakes and ponds<ref name=":10" />. The overflow of pool water acts as an important passive form of [[Seed dispersal|hydrochory]] in which water acts as a vector<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sciullo|first=L.|last2=Kolasa|first2=J.|date=2012|title=Linking local community structure to the dispersal of aquatic invertebrate species in a rock pool metacommunity|url=|journal=Community Ecology|volume=13|pages=203–212|via=JSTOR}}</ref>. Floods displace plants and organisms, whether or not overflow occurs<ref name=":13" />. [[Macrophytes]] and organisms as small as [[zooplankton]] can be transported via flood pulses<ref name=":13" />.
Hurricanes can also act as dispersal vectors. After the 2004 [[Hurricane Charley]] struck Florida, there was a higher reported dispersal of the propagules of red mangrove trees<ref name=":14">{{Cite journal|last=Proffitt|first=C. Edward|date=December 2006|title=Red mangrove (Rhizophora mangle) reproduction and seedling colonization after Hurricane Charley: Comparisons of Charlotte Harbor and Tampa Bay|url=|journal=Estuaries and Coasts|volume=29|pages=972–978|via=}}</ref>. If a hurricane strikes in the later summer months, there is an expected increase in the dispersal of propagules, while early storms can wash out immature propagules and decrease the dispersal of mature propagules for that season<ref name=":14" />.
When extreme weather events occur over an open body of water, they can create intense waves.  These waves can create large dispersal within the water column by changing local water movement, but tend to constrict the actual dispersal distance for smaller organisms<ref name=":4" />.
=== Human-Created Hydrochory === The [[fishing]] industry has introduced new forms in which water acts as a dispersal vector. The water in bait buckets transfers bait everywhere a fisherman takes it, and this can introduce non-native species into areas should this bait water be spilt<ref name=":9" />. This idea is applied on a much larger scale to the ballast tanks of ships<ref name=":9" />. A study done by James Carlton of Williams College reports that more than 3000 species are moving across the ocean in [[Ballast tank|ballast tanks]] on any given day<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Carlton|first=James T.|date=1996|title=Pattern, process, and prediction in marine invasion ecology|url=|journal=Biological Conservation|volume=78|pages=97–106|via=}}</ref>.
Artificial waterways created by humans have also spurred new forms of hydrochory. [[Amphipoda|Amphipods]] were found to be able to cross previously uncrossable areas to enter into new drainage pipe thanks to the construction of a canal<ref name=":9" />.
Artificial waterways not only connect communities that are geographically close, but they also allow for the transmission of invasive species from distant communities<ref name=":10" />. The distribution of invasive species is, in part, regulated by local ocean conditions and currents<ref name=":5" />.
The introduction of human-generated waste, like wood planks and plastic bags, into water sources has increased the amount of viable rafts for dispersal<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kiessling|first=Tim|date=2015|title=Marine litter as habitat and dispersal vector|url=|journal=Marine Anthropogenic Litter|volume=|pages=141–181|via=}}</ref>.
== Human Mediated Dispersal == Humans have been acting as dispersal vectors since we began moving around the planet, bringing non-native plants and animals with us. As trends in [[urbanization]] have increased, urban environments can act as staging grounds for species dispersal and invasion. Many non-native species exist in urban environments and the high rate of movement in an out of urban areas leads to a high level of dispersal to neighboring environments. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=von der Lippe|first=Moritz|date=Spring 2017|title=Do cities export biodiversity? Traffic asdispersal vector across urban–rural gradients|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/store/10.1111/j.1472-4642.2007.00401.x/asset/j.1472-4642.2007.00401.x.pdf;jsessionid=8555AE925BA4D1C18843B13F46A32974.f02t02?v=1&t=j294fnqv&s=78921d79a70a42912d1459f33ed3ab99074443cc|journal=Diversity and Distributions|volume=14|pages=18–25|doi=10.1111/j.1472-4642.2007.00401.x}}</ref>

{{Orphan|date=August 2012}} '''Endogenous regeneration''' in the brain is the ability of cells to engage in the repair and [[Regeneration (biology)#Humans|regeneration]] process. While the brain has a limited capacity for regeneration, [[Endogeny|endogenous]] neural [[stem cell]]s, as well as numerous pro-regenerative molecules, can participate in replacing and repairing damaged or diseased [[neuron]]s and [[Neuroglia|glial cells]]. Another benefit that can be achieved by using endogenous regeneration could be avoiding an [[Immune system|immune]] response from the host.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Odelberg S. J. |year=2002 |title=Indus regeneration in mammals|journal= Cell & Developmental Biology |volume=13 |pages=335–343. |doi=10.1016/s1084-9521(02)00089-7 |pmid= 12324215 |issue=5 }}</ref>
==Neural stem cells in the adult brain== During the early development of a human, [[Nervous system|neural]] stem cells lie in the [[Germ layer|germinal layer]] of the developing brain, [[Ventricular system|ventricular]] and [[subventricular zone]]s. In brain development, [[Multipotent#Multipotency|multipotent]] stem cells (those that can generate different types of cells) are present in these regions, and all of these cells differentiate into neural cell forms, such as [[neurons]], [[oligodendrocytes]] and [[astrocytes]]. A long-held belief states that the multipotency of neural stem cells would be lost in the adult human brain.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Doetsch F, Isabelle C, Lim DA |year=1999 |title=Subventricular Zone Astrocytes Are Neural Stem Cells in the Adult Mammalian Brain |journal=Cell |volume=97 |pages=703–716|doi=10.1016/S0092-8674(00)80783-7|pmid=10380923|issue=6}}</ref> However, it is only ''[[in vitro]]'', using [[neurosphere]] and adherent [[monolayer]] cultures, stem cells that can be found in the adult mammalian brain that have shown mutipotent capacity, while the ''[[in vivo]]'' study is not convincing. Therefore, the term "neural progenitor" is used instead of "stem cell" to describe limited regeneration ability in the adult brain stem cell.<ref name='zhao'>{{cite journal |author=Zhao, C. |author2=Deng, W. |author3=Gage, F. H. |year=2008 |title=Mechanisms and functional implications of adult neurogenesis |journal= Cell |volume=132 |pages=645–660 |doi= 10.1016/j.cell.2008.01.033 |pmid=18295581|issue=4}}</ref>
[[Neural stem cells]] (NSC) reside in the [[subventricular zone]] (SVZ) of the adult human brain and the [[dentate gyrus]] of the adult mammalian [[hippocampus]]. Newly formed neurons from these regions participate in learning, memory, [[olfaction]] and mood modulation.<ref name='zhao' /> It has not been definitively determined whether or not these stem cells are multipotents. NSC from the hippocampus of rodents, which can differentiate into dentate [[granule cell]]s, have developed into many cell types when studied in culture.<ref name='ming'>{{cite journal |author1=Guo-li Ming H. S. |year=2005 |title=Adult Neurogenesis in the Mammalian Central Nervous System |journal=Annu. Rev. Neurosci. |volume=28|pages=223–250. |doi=10.1146/annurev.neuro.28.051804.101459 |pmid=16022595}}</ref> However, another ''in vivo'' study, using NSCs in the postnatal SVZ, showed that the stem cell is restricted to developing into different neuronal sub-type cells in the [[olfactory bulb]]. It is believed that the various spatial location niches regulate the differentiation of the neural stem cell.<ref name='development'>{{cite journal| author=Duan, X. |author2=Kang, E. |author3=Liu, C. Y. |author4=Ming, G. L. |author5=Song, H. |year=2008|title= Development of neural stem cell in the adult brain |journal= Curr Opin Neurobiol |volume=18 | issue = 1 |pages=108–115 |doi= 10.1016/j.conb.2008.04.001|pmc=2464621 }}</ref>
==Neurogenesis in the central nervous system== {{main|neuroregeneration}}
[[Santiago Ramon y Cajal]], a neuroscience pioneer, concluded that the generation of neurons occurs only in the [[Prenatal development|prenatal]] phase of human development, not after birth. This theory had long been the fundamental principle of [[neuroscience]].<ref name='ming' /> However, in the mid-20th century, evidence of adult mammalian [[neurogenesis]] was found in rodent hippocampus and other region of the brain.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Altman J. |title=Autoradiographic and histological studies of postnatal neurogenesis. II. A longitudinal investigation of the kinetics, migration and transformation of cells incorporating tritiated thymidine in infant rats, with special reference to postnatal neurogenesis in some brain regions | year=1966 |journal=J. Comp. Neurol. |pages=431–74 |doi=10.1002/cne.901280404 |volume=128 |issue=4}}</ref> In the intact adult mammalian brain, [[neuroregeneration]] maintains the function and structure of the [[central nervous system]] (CNS). The most adult stem cells in the brain are found in the subventricular zone at the lateral walls of the lateral ventricle. Another region where neurogenesis takes place in the adult brain is the [[subgranular zone]] (SGZ) of the dentate gyrus in the hippocampus. While the exact mechanism that maintains functional NSCs in these regions is still unknown, NSCs have shown an ability to restore neurons and glia in response to certain [[Pathology|pathological]] conditions. However, so far, this regeneration by NSCs is insufficient to restore the full function and structure of an injured brain. However, endogenous neuroregeneration, unlike using embryonic stem cell implantation, is anticipated to treat damaged CNS without immunogenesis or [[Carcinogenesis|tumorigenesis]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Ninette Amariglio A. H. |author2=Bernd W, Scheithauer |author3=Yoram Cohen |year=2009 |title=Donor-Derived Brain Tumor Following Neural Stem Cell Transplantation in an Ataxia Telangiectasia Patient|journal= PLOS Medicine |volume=6 | issue = 2 |pages= 221–231 |url=http://www.plosmedicine.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pmed.1000029 |doi=10.1371/journal.pmed.1000029}}</ref>
==Neurogenesis in subgranular zone== [[Progenitor cells]] in the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus migrate to the nearby location and differentiate into granule cells. As a part of the [[limbic system]], new neurons of the hippocampus maintain the function of controlling mood, learning and memory. In the dentate gyrus, [https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/putative putative] stem cells, called type 1 cells, proliferate into type 2 and type 3 cells, which are transiently amplifying, lineage-determined progenitor cells. Type 1 cells in the hippocampus are multipotent ''in vitro''. However, although there is evidence that both new neurons and glia are generated in the hippocampus ''in vivo'', no exact relationship of neurogenesis to type 1 cells is shown.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Gerd Kempermann |author2=Sebastian Jessberger |author3=Barbara Steiner |author4=Golo Kronenberg |title=Milestones of neuronal development in the adult hippocampus |journal = Trends in Neurosciences |volume = 27 | issue = 8 | year = 2004|doi=10.1016/j.tins.2004.05.013|url=http://www.cell.com/trends/neurosciences//retrieve/pii/S0166223604001675_returnURL=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0166223604001675?showall=true |pages=447–452}}</ref>
In the hippocampus, newly formed neurons contribute only a small portion to the entire neuron population. These new neurons have different [[electrophysiology]] compared to the rest of the existing neurons. This may be evidence that generating new neurons in the SGZ is part of learning and memorizing activity of mammals. Several studies have been performed to explain the relationship between neruogenesis and learning. In the case of learning, that related to the hippocampal function, a significantly increased number of neurons are generated in the SGZ and survival of the new neurons is increased if they are required for retention of memory.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Bendetta Leuner |author2=Sabrina Mendolia-Loffredo |author3=Yevgenia Kozorovitskiy |author4=Deanna Samburg |author5=Elizabeth Gould |author6=Tracey J. Shors |title = Learning Enhances the Survival of New Neurons beyond the Time when the Hippocampus Is Required for Memory |year =2004 |journal = The Journal of Neuroscience |volume =24 | issue = 34 |pages = 7477–7481|url=http://www.jneurosci.org/content/24/34/7477.full.pdf |doi=10.1523/jneurosci.0204-04.2004 |pmid=15329394 |pmc=3279157}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Elizabeth Gould |author2=Anna Beylin |author3=Patima Tanapat |author4=Alison Reeves |author5=Tracey J. Shors |title = Learning enhances adult neurogenesis in the Hippocampal formation |year = 1999 |journal= Nature |volume= 2 |pages= 260–265|url=http://www.nature.com/neuro/journal/v2/n3/full/nn0399_260.html |issue=3 |doi=10.1038/6365 |pmid=10195219}}</ref> In addition to learning and memorizing, neurogenesis in the SGZ is also affected by mood and emotion. With constant, inescapable stress, which usually results in emotional depression, there is a significant decrease in neurogensis, the effect of which can be reversed by treatment with [[fluoxetine]].<ref>{{cite journal |author = Fluoxetine Treatment | year = 2003 |journal = Neuropsychopharmacology |volume = 28 |pages = 1562–1571 |doi=10.1038/sj.npp.1300234 |issue=9 |title = Cell Proliferation in Adult Hippocampus is Decreased by Inescapable Stress: Reversal by Fluoxetine Treatment |pmid = 12838272}}</ref>
==Neurogenesis in subventricular zone== The largest NSC population in the brain is found in the SVZ. The SVZ is considered a micro-environment called a "stem cell niche" that retains the NSC's capacity of self-renewing and multipotency. Basic [[fibroblast]] growth factor (FGF2), [[hepatocyte growth factor]] (HGF), [[Notch-1]], [[sonic hedgehog]] (SHH), [[Noggin (protein)|noggin]], [[ciliary neurotrophic factor]] (CNTF), and a soluble carbohydrate-binding protein, [[Galectin-1]], are reported as factors that maintain such properties of NSC in stem cell niche. Like stem cells in SGZ, progenitor cells in SVZ also differentiate into neurons and form an intermediate cell called a transiently amplifying cell (TAC). A recent study revealed that [[beta-catenin]] signaling, Wnt β-catenin, regulates the differentiation of TAC.<ref name='gene'>{{cite journal |author1=Naoko Kaneko |author2=Eisuke Kako |author3=Kazunobu Sawamoto |title=Prospects and Limitations of Using Endogenous Neural Stem Cells for Brain Regeneration |year =2011 |journal = Genes |volume = 2 |pages = 107–130 |doi = 10.3390/genes2010107 | issue =4}}</ref>
NSCs in the SVZ have a distinct capacity to migrate into the olfactory bulb in the anterior tip of the [[Cerebrum|telencephalon]] by a pathway called the [[rostral migratory stream]] (RMS). This migration is unique to new neurons in the SVZ that embryonic neurogenesis and nerogenesis at other region of the brain are not able to perform. Another unique neurogensis in the SVZ is neurogenesis by astrocytes. A study done by Doetsch (1999) showed that astrocytes in the SVZ can be dedifferentiate and differentiate into neurons in the olfactory bulb. Among four types of cells in the SVZ (migrating neuroblasts, immature precursors, astrocytes, and [[ependyma]]l cells), migrating neuroblasts and immature precursors are silenced with the anti-[[Mitosis|mitotic]] agent and astrocytes are infected with a [[retrovirus]]. In the result, neurons that have the retrovirus are found in the olfactory bulb.<ref>{{cite journal |author = Doetsch, F. |author2=Isabelle, C. |author3=Lim, D. A. |title=Subventricular Zone Astrocytes Are Neural Stem Cells in the Adult Mammalian Brain |year=1999 |journal = Cell |pages= 703–716 |volume=97 |doi = 10.1016/S0092-8674(00)80783-7 |pmid = 10380923 |issue = 6}}</ref>
==Factors affecting neurogenesis== Neurogenesis in the adult mammalian brain is affected by various factors, including exercise, [[stroke]], brain [[Insult (medical)|insult]] and pharmacological treatments. For example, [[kainic acid]]-induced seizures, antidepressant ([[fluoxetine]]), [[neurotransmitter]]s such as [[GABA]] and growth factors ([[fibroblast growth factors]] (FGFs), [[epidermal growth factor]] (EGF), [[neuregulins]] (NRGs), [[vascular endothelial growth factor]] (VEGF), and [[pigment epithelium-derived factor]] (PEDF) induce formation of neuroblasts. The final destination of NSCs is determined by "niche" signals. [[Wnt signaling pathway|Wnt]] signaling drives NSCs to the formation of new neurons in the SGZ, whereas bone [[Morphogenesis|morphogenic]] proteins (BMPs) promote NSC differentiation into glia cells in the SVZ.<ref name='development' />
However, in the case of brain injury, neurogenesis seems insufficient to repair damaged neurons. Thus, Cajal's theory was accepted for a long time. In actuality, in the intercranial physiological condition, many neurogenesis inhibitors are present (for example, [[axon]] growth-inhibitory [[ligand]]s expressed in [[oligodendrocytes]], [[myelin]], NG2-glia, and reactive astrocytes in the lesion and degenerating tracts, and fibroblasts in scar tissue). The inhibitory ligands bind to [[growth cone]] receptors on a damaged neuron, which causes repulsion and collapse of the growth cone in the damaged regions. Among inhibitory factors, oligodendrocyte and myelin-derived inhibitory ligands are membrane-bound, meaning that, in the case of injury, those factors are not upregulated or overexpressed, rather it is from direct contact between intact or degraded myelin (or oligodendrocytes) and newly forming neurons.
Nevertheless, with scar formation, many cell types in the brain release growth-inhibitory ligands such as [[basal lamina]] components, inhibitory axon guidance molecules and [[chondroitin sulfate proteoglycan]]s.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=AXEL SANDVIG |author2=MARTIN BERRY |author3=LEE B. BARRETT |author4=ARTHUR BUTT |author5=AND ANN LOGAN |title=Myelin-, Reactive Glia-, and Scar-Derived CNS Axon Growth Inhibitors:Expression, Receptor Signaling, and Correlation with Axon Regeneration |journal =GLIA |year=2004 |volume =46 |pages=225–251 | doi= 10.1002/glia.10315 | pmid= 15048847 | issue= 3}}</ref> Inhibitory action of such factors may be a protection of the brain from inflammation. Okano and Sawamoto used an astrocyte-selective conditional [[Stat3]]-deficient mice model to examine the role of reactive astrocytes. The result was increased widespread [[CD11b]]-positive inflammatory cell invasion and [[Demyelinating disease|demyelination]].<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Hideyuki Okano |author2=Kazunobu Sawamoto |title=Neural stem cells: involvement in adult neurogenesis and CNS repair |year=2012 |journal = Phil. Trans. R. Soc. B |volume=363 |pages=2111–2122 |doi =10.1098/rstb.2008.2264 | issue =1500 | pmid =18339601 | pmc =2610183}}</ref>
==Application== Brain damage itself can induce endogenous regeneration. Many studies have proven endogenous regeneration as a possible treatment of brain damage. However, the inhibitory reaction of the surrounding tissue of damaged region must be overcome before the treatment produces significant improvement.
===Traumatic brain injury=== In the study of the endogenous regeneration of the brain done by Scharff and co-researchers, damaged neurons in a songbird brain are regenerated with the same neuronal types where regeneration occurs (in the case of the study, the hippocampus). However, in places where normal regeneration of the neuron does not occur, there was no replacement of damaged neurons.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Scharff C, Kirn JR, Grossman M, Macklis JD, Nottebohm F |title =Targeted neuronal death affects neuronal replacement and vocal behavior in adult songbirds |journal=Neuron |year =2002|pages =481–492 |volume=25 |doi=10.1016/S0896-6273(00)80910-1 |issue=2}}</ref> Thus, recovering brain function after a brain injury was supposed to have limitations. However, a current study revealed that neurons are repaired to some degree after damage, from the SVZ.
The migrating ability of progenitor cells in the SVZ form chain-like structures and laterally move progenitor cells towards the injured region. Along with progenitor cells, thin astrocytic processes and blood vessels also play an important role in the migration of neuroblasts, suggesting that the blood vessels may act as a scaffold. Other factors that contribute of the migration are [[Slit (gene family)|slit proteins]] (produced at the [[choroid plexus]]) and their gradient (generated by the flow of [[cerebrospinal fluid]]). However, only 0.2% of new neurons survived and functioned in this study. Enhancing neurogenesis can be done by injecting growth factors such as fibroblast growth factor-2 (FGF-2) and epidermal growth factor (EGF). However, enhanced neurogenesis also have the possibility of [[epilepsy]] resulting in prolonged seizures.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Okano H, Sakaguchi M, Ohki K, Suzuki N, Sawamoto K |title=Regeneration of the central nervous system using endogenous repair mechanisms |year=2007 |journal =J Neurochem |pages=1459–1465 |volume=102 |doi=10.1111/j.1471-4159.2007.04674.x |issue=5}}</ref>
===Parkinson's Disease=== Although endogenous regeneration methods are showing some promising evidence in treating [[brain ischemia]], the current body of knowledge regarding promoting and inhibiting endogenous regeneration is not sufficient to treat [[Parkinson's disease]]. Both extrinsic and intrinsic modulation of pathological and physiological stimulation prevent the progenitor cell from differentiating into [[dopamine]] cells. Further research must be done to understand factors that affect progenitor cell differentiation in order to treat Parkinson's disease.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Andreas Hermann |author2=Alexander Storch |title=Endogenous Regeneration in Parkinson's Disease: Do We Need Orthotopic Dopaminergic Neurogenesis? |year=2008 |journal=Stem Cells |volume=26 |pages=2749–2752 |doi=10.1634/stemcells.2008-0567 |issue=11 |pmid=18719222}}</ref>
Despite the difficulties in replacing compromised dopamine neurons through endogenous sources, recent work suggests that pharmacological activation of endogenous [[neural stem cell]]s or neural precursor cells results in powerful neuronal rescue and motor skill improvements through a signal [[Transduction (biophysics)|transduction]] pathway that involves the [[phosphorylation]] of [[STAT3]] on the [[serine]] residue and subsequent Hes3 expression increase ([[Hes3 signaling axis|STAT3-Ser/Hes3 Signaling Axis]]).<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Androutsellis-Theotokis A, Rueger MA, Park DM |title=Targeting neural precursors in the adult brain rescues injured dopamine neurons |journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. |volume=106 |issue=32 |pages=13570–5 |date=August 2009 |pmid=19628689 |pmc=2714762 |doi=10.1073/pnas.0905125106 |url=|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Androutsellis-Theotokis A, Rueger MA, Mkhikian H, Korb E, McKay RD |title=Signaling pathways controlling neural stem cells slow progressive brain disease |journal=Cold Spring Harb. Symp. Quant. Biol. |volume=73 |issue= |pages=403–10 |year=2008 |pmid=19022746 |doi=10.1101/sqb.2008.73.018 |url=}}</ref>

Smith, Stephen Vantassel | frequency = biannually | discipline = [[Theology]] | publisher = Midlands Bible College | history = 2006-2012 | country = [[United Kingdom]] | website = http://www.evangelicalreview.com | ISSN = 1750-2217 | eISSN = 1750-2225 | abbreviation = Evangelical Rev. Soc. Politics }} The '''''Evangelical Review of Society and Politics''''' was a [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]], scholarly [[List of theological journals|theological journal]] published by the [[King's Evangelical Divinity School]], [[England]]. It was published biannually in both print and electronic formats. The journal defined its scope as "scholarly evangelical analysis of contemporary social and political issues".
It has subsequently been replaced by a similar journal in electronic form only [[Evangelical Review of Theology and Politics]] and published by the same source.
== External links == * [http://collegeblog.midbible.ac.uk/ Midlands Bible College blog] where many issues relevant to the journal are posted.

{{Infobox protein family | Symbol = DAO | Name = FAD dependent oxidoreductase | image = PDB 1c0i EBI.jpg | width = | caption = crystal structure of d-amino acid oxidase in complex with two anthranylate molecules | Pfam = PF01266 | Pfam_clan = CL0063 | InterPro = IPR006076 | SMART = | PROSITE = PDOC00753 | MEROPS = | SCOP = 1kif | TCDB = | OPM family = | OPM protein = | CAZy = | CDD = | Membranome superfamily = 249 }} In molecular biology, the '''FAD dependent oxidoreductase family''' of proteins is a family of [[flavin adenine dinucleotide|FAD]] dependent [[oxidoreductases]]. Members of this family include [[Glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase]] {{EC number|1.1.99.5}}, [[Sarcosine oxidase]] beta subunit {{EC number|1.5.3.1}}, [[D-amino-acid dehydrogenase]] {{EC number|1.4.99.1}}, [[D-aspartate oxidase]] {{EC number|1.4.3.1}}.
[[D-amino acid oxidase]] {{EC number|1.4.3.3}} (DAMOX or DAO) is an FAD flavoenzyme that [[Catalysis|catalyses]] the [[redox|oxidation]] of neutral and basic D-[[amino acids]] into their corresponding keto acids. DAOs have been characterised and [[sequenced]] in [[fungus|fungi]] and [[vertebrates]] where they are known to be located in the [[peroxisomes]].
[[D-aspartate oxidase]] {{EC number|1.4.3.1}} (DASOX) <ref name="pmid1601857">{{cite journal |vauthors=Negri A, Ceciliani F, Tedeschi G, Simonic T, Ronchi S | title = The primary structure of the flavoprotein D-aspartate oxidase from beef kidney | journal = J. Biol. Chem. | volume = 267 | issue = 17 | pages = 11865–71 |date=June 1992 | pmid = 1601857 | doi = | url = }}</ref> is an enzyme, [[structurally]] related to DAO, which catalyses the same reaction but is active only toward dicarboxylic D-amino acids. In DAO, a [[conserved sequence|conserved]] [[histidine]] has been shown <ref name="pmid1673125">{{cite journal |vauthors=Miyano M, Fukui K, Watanabe F, Takahashi S, Tada M, Kanashiro M, Miyake Y | title = Studies on Phe-228 and Leu-307 recombinant mutants of porcine kidney D-amino acid oxidase: expression, purification, and characterization | journal = J. Biochem. | volume = 109 | issue = 1 | pages = 171–7 |date=January 1991 | pmid = 1673125 | doi = | url = }}</ref> to be important for the [[enzyme]]'s [[catalytic]] activity.
==See also== * [[DAO (disambiguation)|DAO]] * [[D-amino-acid dehydrogenase]] * [[D-amino acid oxidase]] * [[D-aspartate oxidase]] * [[Glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase]] * [[Sarcosine oxidase]]

[[Image:GCN.PNG|300px|thumb|Diagram of the Gamma ray burst Coordinates Network. (NASA/GSFC)]] The '''gamma-ray burst coordinates network''' ('''GCN''') is a system that distributes information about the location of a [[gamma-ray burst]] (GRB), called ''notices'', when a burst is detected by various spacecraft. The GCN also automatically receives and distributes messages, called ''circulars'', about follow-up observations to interested individuals and institutions. Follow-up observations may be made by ground-based and space-based optical, radio, and X-ray observatories.
GCN has its origins in the BATSE coordinates distribution network (BACODINE). The Burst And Transient Source Experiment ([[BATSE]]) was a scientific instrument on the ''[[Compton Gamma-Ray Observatory]]'' (CGRO), and BACODINE monitored the BATSE real-time telemetry from CGRO. The first function of BACODINE was calculating the [[right ascension]] (RA) and [[declination]] (dec) locations for GRBs that it detected, and distributing those locations to sites around the world in real-time. Since the de-orbiting of the CGRO, this function of BACODINE is no longer operational. The second function of BACODINE was collecting right ascension and declination locations of GRBs detected by spacecraft other than CGRO, and then distributing that information. With this functionality, the original BACODINE name was changed to the more general name GCN.
==GCN data flow== The GCN data flow starts when gamma-rays from a GRB hit a detector on a spacecraft. The spacecraft sends the GRB location information down to a ground station, which in turn relays it to the GCN at the [[NASA]] [[Goddard Space Flight Center]]. At GSFC the location information is processed by GCN with custom hardware and software, and then Notices are sent to users via [[Inter-process communication|socket connection]], [[e-mail]], and [[pager]]s. Those users may then schedule follow-up observations of the GRB, and send refined information about the GRB back to the GCN.
In the case of ''[[Swift Gamma-Ray Burst Mission|Swift]]'', the GRB location information follows the same path, except it is transmitted from ''Swift'' up to a [[TDRS]] satellite, and then down to the [[TDRSS#Ground segment|White Sands Complex]] (WSC). From WSC, the location information is sent to GSFC via a domestic communications satellite (DOMSAT).
==GCN notices== The following spacecraft, and instruments where noted, are sources of real-time GCN information:
*''[[High Energy Transient Explorer]]'' (WMM and SXC) *''INTErnational Gamma-Ray Astrophysics Laboratory'' ([[INTEGRAL]]) *[[InterPlanetary Network]] (IPN) Position Notices from ''[[WIND (spacecraft)|WIND]]'' (Konus) and ''[[Ulysses probe|Ulysses]]''. *''[[Rossi X-ray Timing Explorer]]'' (PCA and ASM) *''[[Swift Gamma-Ray Burst Mission|Swift]]'' provides data products not previously available from prior missions, including [[Electromagnetic spectrum#Spectra of objects|spectra]], images, and [[lightcurve]]s.
Past spacecraft and instruments that participated in GCN include ''[[Array of Low Energy X-ray Imaging Sensors]]'' (''ALEXIS''), ''[[BeppoSAX]]'', the Imaging Compton Telescope (COMPTEL) on CGRO, and the X-Ray/Gamma-Ray Spectrometer (XGRS) on ''[[NEAR Shoemaker]]''.
==GCN circulars== The GCN system has the capability to receive and distribute timely information on GRBs called GCN Circulars. Users e-mail their reports to a central location and then those reports will be automatically sent to an e-mail distribution list. This list of Circular recipients is completely separate from the list of Notice recipients. The GCN Observation Report Circulars allow the GRB follow-up community to make optimum use of limited resources, such as labor and telescope time, by communicating what has already been done or will soon be done.
==Future plans for GCN== To maximize the utility of the GCN system, GCN will make whatever modifications are necessary to incorporate and distribute GRB location information from new spacecraft and instruments as they become active. GCN will also expand its operations to include information about any astrophysical transients, including non-GRBs such as the [[UV astronomy|extreme-ultraviolet]] transients detected by the ''ALEXIS'' spacecraft. Future spacecraft that will be distributing GRB locations via GCN include ''[[AGILE (spacecraft)|AGILE]]'' and ''[[Gamma-ray Large Area Space Telescope]]''.
==External links== *[http://gcn.gsfc.nasa.gov/ GCN Homepage at GSFC]

[[File:Gotham_Writers_Workshop_Winter_2015.jpg|thumb|right]]
'''Gotham Writers Workshop''' is the [[United States]]'s largest adult-education writing school.<ref>New York Press, April 15, 2003</ref> It was founded in New York City in 1993 by writers Jeff Fligelman and David Grae. It was one of the first schools to offer online education, launching its online creative writing classes in 1997.<ref>Byles, Jeff. ''The Write Stuff'' The Village Voice, August 05, 2003</ref>
The workshop offers courses in most of the major genres including fiction and novel writing, screenwriting and television, poetry, and several forms of creative nonfiction, including essay writing and memoir.<ref name="writingclasses">{{cite web|url=http://www.writingclasses.com/|title=Gotham Writers' Workshop - Creative Writing Classes in NY and Online|publisher=writingclasses.com|accessdate=2014-06-01}}</ref>
It also runs fiction and screenwriting classes in partnership with ''Zoetrope: All Story'', the literary magazine founded by Francis Ford Coppola and Adrienne Brodeur and edited by Michael Ray.<ref>[[Zoetrope: All-Story]]</ref>
Gotham Writers Workshop has produced three books, edited by school President Alexander Steele: ''Writing Fiction'', ''Fiction Gallery'', and ''Writing Movies''. They've also been translated and published in several languages.
The workshop also publishes a monthly newsletter with writing articles by its faculty and others.
== Faculty ==
Gotham faculty are all working writers, published in their fields and experienced teachers. Recent faculty include: Novelist Susan Breen,<ref name="thefictionclass">{{cite web|url=http://www.thefictionclass.com/about.htm|title=Susan Breen - The Fiction Class|publisher=thefictionclass.com|accessdate=2014-06-01}}</ref> playwright Richard Caliban, memoirist and novelist [[Kerry Cohen]], novelist and former Random House senior editor [[Anita Doreen Diggs|Anita Diggs]], longtime ''New York Times'' editor and author Francis Flaherty, travel writer and novelist [[James Bernard Frost]], television writer Kellye Garrett, novelist [[Shari Goldhagen]], fiction writer [http://www.writingclasses.com/FacultyBios/facultyBioByInstructor.php/TeacherID/116175 Manuel Gonzales], screenwriter Doug Katz, young-adult novelist [[The Duff (novel)|Kody Keplinger]], Oscar-winning screenwriter and director [[Jennifer Lee (filmmaker)|Jennifer Lee]], science fiction novelist [[Daniel Marcus]], TV writer and comedian [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3920816/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk1 Jim Mendrinos], short-story writer [[Kyle Minor]], memoirist [[Julie Powell]], science fiction writer [[Michaela Roessner]], memoirist [[Domenica Ruta]], fiction writer Hasanthika Sirisena,<ref name="writingclasses2">{{cite web|url=http://www.writingclasses.com/FacultyBios/facultyBioByInstructor.php/TeacherID/39868|title=Hasanthika Sirisena Faculty Biographies at Gotham Writers' Workshop and WritingClasses.com|publisher=writingclasses.com|accessdate=2014-06-01}}</ref> journalist Steven James Snyder,<ref name="time">{{cite web|url=http://newsfeed.time.com/author/stevos23/|title=Steven James Snyder | TIME.com|publisher=newsfeed.time.com|accessdate=2014-06-01}}</ref> TV writer (and former supervising producer of ''[[Bones (season 1)|Bones]]'') Laura Wolner, fiction writer and humorist [[David Yoo]], and radio show host and author, [http://www.penonfire.com Barbara DeMarco-Barrett].
== Student body ==
Students who began work on successful projects at Gotham include memoirist Annette Berkovits, (''In The Unlikeliest Of Places'', Wilfrid Laurier University Press, 2014); essayist Chloe Caldwell (''Legs Get Led Astray'', Future Tense Books, 2012 and ''Women'', Future Tense Books, 2015); middle-grade novelist Josh Farrar, (''Rules to Rock By'' and ''A Song For Bijou'', both Bloomsbury USA, 2013 and 2014, respectively); TV Writer [[Wendy Riss Gatsiounis|Wendy Riss]]; fiction writer Chris Tarry, (''How To Carry Bigfoot Home'', forthcoming by Red Hen Press); and screenwriter Kelly Winsa, (''Hi Honey'', 2012).<ref>[http://www.writingclasses.com/index-yii.php/lettersToGotham Letters To Gotham]</ref>
